test

Class TestObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • test.TestObject

  • public class TestObject
extends java.lang.Object
    Gives you the ability to test a class you don't know the implementation of. We will from now on be referencing this class as the "tested class".
    This class encapsulates the tested class. Use the constructors of TestObject to get instances of the tested class. You can use the run and runStatic methods to run methods on the instance.
    To point a test to the implementation it should test, set a JVM variable className to the name of the tested class via the -D command. Example: "-DclassName=de.joshuagleitze.tuple.NaturalNumberTuple"

    Calling the constructors and run...-methods

    In the following, we will talk about "run methods". By this term, the constructors, runStatic, runStatic, run, runVoid are meant.
    formal arguments
    Which method of the implemented class to run will be decided based on the formalArguments parameter. But most of the time, you don't have explicitly specify the type of the arguments. If you call a run method without the formalArguments parameter, the formal parameters of the method will be guessed based on the classes of the arguments parameter. If there is no method whose formal arguments match formalArguments or the guessed argument types, Assert.fail() will be called to output an error message.

    90% of the time, you don't have to specify argument types. There are some special cases though:

    Primitive wrapper classes
    Instances of primitive wrapper classes will be guessed as primitive types! For example, to call
    public static void foo(Integer x),
    you'll have to specify the argument types, e.g. like this:
    TestObject.runStaticVoid("foo", new Class[]{Integer.getClass()}, new Integer(3))

    Instances of TestObject
    will always be converted into the instance of the tested class. This applies even if they are nested in an array.

    Inheritance
    If you want to call a method in the tested class but specify an argument that is a subclass of the method's formal argument, the subclass will be guessed an most likely an error message will occur, as the there is no such method in the implemented class. For example, to call
    public static void foo(Number x) with 3,
    you'll have to specify the argument types, e.g. like this:
    TestObject.runStaticVoid("foo", new Class[]{ Number.getClass()}, 3).

    Passing an array
    Because of the run method's signatures, you have to convert an array to Object if you pass it as as the only argument. For example, calling a main method may look like this:
    TestObject.runStaticVoid("main", (Object) new String[]{"arg1", "arg2"})

    return type
    Run methods ending with "Void" can only be used to call void methods. If there is a method in the test class that matches the arguments you provided, but it is not a void method, Assert.fail() will be called to output an error message.

    For the other run methods, you specify the expected return type through expectedReturnType. If a method of the tested class matches the arguments provided but does not return an instance of expectedReturnType, Assert.fail() will be called to output an error message.

    Conversion
    A returned object that is an instance of the tested class will be converted to an instance of TestObject that represent it. This applies even if it is nested in an array.

    error messages
    The run methods will output error messages via Assert.fail() in the following cases:
    • There is no method matching the formal parameters defined in formalArguments or implied by arguments, respectively.
    • Such a method exits, but it's not accessible for TestObject (<=> not public).
    • An exception that was not set to be rethrown with rethrowExceptions(Class...) is thrown while running the method.
    • The method is not a void method or does not return an instance of the class specified in expectedReturnType, respectively.
    • Some other strange cases that should not occur.
    exception handling
    As mentioned above, normally Assert.fail() is called to output an error message if an exception is thrown while running a method. You can change that behaviour by calling rethrowExceptions(Class...). If the exception thrown in the tested class is an instance of the specified classes, it is wrapped in a TestMethodException which is then thrown. For example, if we would like to test that a method throws a FooException, we would do the following: 
     
 TestObject.rethrowException(FooException);
 try {
      TestObject.runStaticVoid("theMethod");
      fail("You are expected to throw a FooException!");
 } catch (TestMethodException e) {
      if (e.getCause() instanceof FooException) {
          // everything went well
      }
 }
    static fields
    If you test methods, it might happen that the implementation you test uses static fields. Especially when you test a main method, you usually want to the test the class in the state it is when the program is started. Otherwise, consecutive calls of main may result in different results! So whenever you test a main method or something that shall only be called once per program run, make sure to use resetClass(): 
     
 TestObject.resetClass(); // Always reset the class before running main!
 TestObject.runStaticVoid("main");
    Version:
    2.1
    Author:
    Joshua Gleitze

    • Constructor Detail

      • TestObject

        public TestObject(java.lang.Class<?>[] formalArguments,
          java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Constructs an TestObject that represents an instance of the tested class. The constructor of the tested class whose formal arguments match argumentTypes will be selected to construct this instance.
        Parameters:
        formalArguments - The classes of the test class' constructor's formal arguments. The constructor will be selected based on the classes you provide.
        arguments - The arguments to be passed to the constructor.

      • TestObject

        public TestObject(java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Constructs an TestObject that represents an instance of the tested class. The constructor of the tested class whose formal arguments match the classes of arguments will be selected to construct this instance.
        Parameters:
        arguments - The arguments to be passed to the constructor of the tested class in the correct order. The constructor will be selected based on their types.

    • Method Detail

      • allowSystemExit

        public static void allowSystemExit(TestObject.SystemExitStatus status)
        Calling this method sets the policy for the tested class to call System.exit(int). Setting this will apply throughout the test, unless you call this method again. The default is that the tested class is not allowed to call System.exit(int) in any way (this status can be achieved by calling allowSystemExit(SystemExitStatus.NONE) . Assert.fail(java.lang.String) will be called if the tested class tries to call System.exit with a status it is not allowed to.
        Parameters:
        status - The status you want to allow calling System.exit(int) with.

      • getLastMethodOutput

        public static java.lang.String getLastMethodOutput()
        Gets the output to System.out of the last run method.
        Returns:
        What the method that was last run using TestObject printed to System.out

      • getPackageName

        public static java.lang.String getPackageName()
        Gets the package the tested class is in.
        Returns:
        The name of the package the tested class is in. If the tested class has no package (= is in the default package null is returned.

      • getSimpleName

        public static java.lang.String getSimpleName()
        Returns the simple name of the tested class.
        Returns:
        What object.class.getSimpleName() returns if object is an instance of the tested class.

      • hasMethod

        public static boolean hasMethod(java.lang.String methodName,
                java.lang.Class<?>... formalArguments)
        Returns whether the tested class implements a method called methodName that takes multiple arguments of the types specified in argumentTypes.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to check for.
        formalArguments - The types of the formal arguments.
        Returns:
        True if such a method is present in the tested class.

      • renderMethodCall

        public static java.lang.String renderMethodCall(java.lang.String methodName,
                                java.lang.Object[] parameters,
                                boolean isConstructor)
        Returns a String that represents a call of a method.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The method's name
        parameters - parameters that were used to call the method.
        isConstructor - Whether the method call was a call to the constructor. If set to true, methodName will be ignored and the tested class' name will be used to render the method call.
        Returns:
        A String of the form "method(object1, object2, ...)"

      • renderMethodFormal

        public static java.lang.String renderMethodFormal(java.lang.String methodName,
                                  java.lang.Class<?>[] formalArguments,
                                  boolean isStatic,
                                  boolean isConstructor)
        Returns a String that represents the formal declaration of a method.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The method's name
        formalArguments - the classes of the method's formal parameters.
        isStatic - Whether the method called was static.
        isConstructor - Whether the method call was a call to the constructor. If set to true, methodName and isStatic will be ignored and the class name will be used to render the method call.
        Returns:
        A String of the form "constructor/method/static method method(class1, class2, ...)"

      • resetClass

        public static void resetClass()
        Resets the tested class. Resetting the tested class means that it will be in the state it was when the program was started. Especially all static fields will be reset to their initial values.

      • rethrowExceptions

        @SafeVarargs
public static void rethrowExceptions(java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Exception>... exceptionClasses)
        Sets which Exceptions will be rethrown (wrapped in a TestMethodException) instead of outputting an error message. If an exception occurs while running a run method, Assert#fail() is normally called to output an error message. But if you expect the test class to throw an exception, it can instead be rethrown. If an exception that is an instance of a class in exceptionClasses occurs while running a tested method, it will be wrapped in a TestMethodException which will then be thrown. The setting applies until rethrowExceptions is called again. To rethrow all exceptions, call rethrowExceptions(Exception.class). To always output an error message (which is the default), run rethrowExceptions() or rethrowExceptions(null).
        Parameters:
        exceptionClasses - If an exception occurs that is an instance of an exception class in exceptionClasses, it will be rethrown.

      • runStatic

        public static <T> T runStatic(java.lang.Class<T> expectedReturnType,
              java.lang.String methodName,
              java.lang.Class<?>[] formalArguments,
              java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Runs a static method on the tested class. The method named methodName taking the formal arguments formalArguments will be selected.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The return type. (Set trough expectedReturnType).
        Parameters:
        expectedReturnType - Class<T> what you expect the method to return.
        methodName - The name of the static method you want to call.
        formalArguments - The method's formal argument's classes. By them, the method will be selected.
        arguments - The arguments you want to pass to the method.
        Returns:
        What the method returns.

      • runStatic

        public static <T> T runStatic(java.lang.Class<T> expectedReturnType,
              java.lang.String methodName,
              java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Runs a static method on the tested class. The method named methodName taking the classes of arguments as formal arguments will be selected.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The return type. (Set trough expectedReturnType).
        Parameters:
        expectedReturnType - Class<T> what you expect the method to return.
        methodName - The name of the static method you want to call.
        arguments - The arguments you want to pass to the method.
        Returns:
        What the method returns.

        arguments - The arguments you want to pass to the method.

      • setNextMethodCallInput

        public static void setNextMethodCallInput(java.lang.String input)
        Provides input for the next method call. The String you provide will be accessible for the tested program through the Terminal class.

        NOTE: While TestObject is independent, the functionality provided by this very method relies on the Terminal class introduced for the programming lecture at the KIT!
        Assert.fail(java.lang.String) will be called to output an error if this method is used by a test but the implementation of the tested class lacks the Terminal class.
        Parameters:
        input - the input that should be provided through the Terminal class on the next method call.

      • translateAllToTestObject

        public static java.lang.Object[] translateAllToTestObject(java.lang.Object[] objects)
        Calls translateToTestObject(Object) on an Array of objects.
        Parameters:
        objects - the objects to convert
        Returns:
        A copy of objects where any occurrence of an instance of the tested class has been converted to an instance of TestObject that represents it.

      • translateToTestObject

        public static java.lang.Object translateToTestObject(java.lang.Object object)
        Converts an instance of the tested class into an instance of TestObject that represents it.
        Parameters:
        object - an object to convert
        Returns:
        If object's class is the tested class, an instance of TestObject that represents is. object is returned without modification otherwise.
